tossups.answer: Russia [accept Soviet Union or USSR] (Every person in this tossup was alive during either the formation or the fall of the Soviet Union; the conductors in the first two sentences are Vasily Petrenko and Valery Gergiev, respectively.)

parts: Name these molecules which have a net charge of zero, but contain multiple functional groups which carry fully separated positive or negative charges which cancel each other out.
The quintessential examples of a zwitterion are these biological monomers, the simplest of which is glycine. These monomers make up peptides and proteins.

N,N,N-trimethylglycine (“N-N-N-try-MEH-thil-GLY-seen”) is one of these compounds, defined as zwitterions where the cationic (“cat-eye-ON-ick”) group does not contain a hydrogen. These compounds were named after the sugar-producing plant from which that glycine derivative was isolated.

answers: Britain [or the United Kingdom; or the UK]
parts: Name this theater movement of the 1990s and 2000s, which often aims to be vulgar and shocking. This movement includes Anthony Neilson, Mark Ravenhill, and Sarah Kane.
The in-yer-face theater movement largely springs from this country, which also gave birth to "angry young men" like Kingsley Amis in the 1950s.
This seminal play of the "angry young men" depicts the working-class Jimmy leaving his upper-class wife Alison for her friend Helena, before they reconcile by pretending to be "bears and squirrels."

answers: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints [or Mormonism or LDS]
parts: Name this sacrament in which a Christian congregation ingests wine and bread to commemorate Jesus’ Last Supper.
Communion is sometimes observed via this process, in which communicants dip a piece of bread into a chalice of wine and ingest the two together.
Members of this church consume water instead of wine for the sacrament. This church broadly prohibits its adherents from drinking any alcohol as dictated by the Word of Wisdom.
Name this country home to Emily Kngwarreye (“ING-wur-eye”) and a contemporary indigenous art movement that began at Papunya in this country’s Northern Territory.

This action titles many abstract paintings by Emily Kngwarreye, with many collected at the Aboriginal Gallery of [this action]. Her paintings may refer to a primordial period in Aboriginal myth named for this action.
Kngwarreye began her career creating textiles using this technique popular in Southeast Asia, which involves coating parts of the cloth with wax and dyeing them to create a negative image.

answers: Conservative Party of Canada [or Liberal-Conservative Party of Canada]
parts: Name this legislative house opposite the Canadian House of Commons for which women were deemed eligible appointees by the 1929 Persons Case.

Prior to the Persons case, this prime minister denied a request to appoint Emily Murphy to the Senate on the grounds that women were not “persons” according to the British North America Act. This prime minister faced riots over conscription during WWI.

Four months after the Persons Case, Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King appointed Cairene Wilson as Canada’s first female senator because Emily Murphy belonged to this party that rivaled King’s Liberals.

answers: Magellanic Clouds [accept Large Magellanic Cloud AND Small Magellanic Cloud]
parts: Name this pair of irregular galaxies that, along with Andromeda, are the only galaxies visible to the naked eye.

This event in the Large Magellanic Cloud generated a flood of neutrinos, twenty-five of which were detected on Earth, providing data on the mass of neutrinos and the mechanism of the gravitational collapse which caused this event.

Alcock et. al. observed light from the Large Magellanic Cloud undergoing microlensing due to dark matter in this region of the Milky Way. This spherical region contains most of the galaxy’s globular clusters and dark matter.

answers: life [or “My Sister Life” or “Sestra moya zhizin”]
parts: Name this author, whose most famous poem describes “spring rain shattering itself like glass” and compares “the timetable on the Kamyshin line” to the Bible as “the carriage throws window-light over the steppe.”
Pasternak framed twenty-five poems including “Hamlet,” “Miracle,” and “The Garden of Gethsemane” as the works of this doctor, and placed them at the end of a novel titled for him.

One of Pasternak’s poems states that this thing is “overflowing today” - that poem called “My Sister” [this thing] titles one of his collections. “Hamlet” ends by saying that this thing “is not a walk across a field.”
Name this “symphonic suite” by Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov, based on A Thousand and One Nights.

In “The Legend of the Kalendar Prince,” this instrument introduces the prince’s theme after the violin plays Scheherazade’s. This instrument also introduces the main theme of the “Berceuse” or “Lullaby” in Stravinsky’s Firebird.

This other composer’s Aladdin Suite originated as incidental music to a play based on A Thousand and One Nights. In this composer’s fourth symphony, two sets of timpani “attack” each other with dissonant tritones.
Name this Rhode Island Senator who sponsored a compromise tariff with Sereno Payne that split Taft’s Republican Party.

Aldrich toured Europe as the chair of the National Monetary Commission to investigate solutions to a panic brought on by the collapse of this bank. J.P. Morgan guided the response to the 1907 collapse of this trust.
The Aldrich Plan produced by the National Monetary Commission recommended a central banking system that was implemented as this institution, currently chaired by Jerome Powell.

answers: subgame perfect Nash equilibrium [or SPNE; or subgame perfect equilibrium; or SPE; prompt on equilibrium or Nash equilibrium or perfect Nash equilibrium]
parts: Extensive-form games allow for conditions that use this adjective or its opposite. "Information" described by this adjective applies when both players know every past event in a game, and "competition" described by this adjective is characterized by a homogeneous market of price-takers.
For a game with perfect information, this is the strategy profile in which all nodes are assigned actions that maximize a player’s payoff.
Deriving subgame perfect equilibria via sequential rationality is the best way to avoid a situation where an irrational player introduces a threat described by this adjective.

answers: funeral [or burial; or wake; or obvious equivalents; prompt on death]
parts: Name this Robert Hayden poem about the speaker’s father, who woke up early to heat the home on a cold morning without ever being thanked. It asks “what did I know / of love’s austere and lonely offices?”
A woman enjoys “late coffee and oranges in a sunny chair” and the “complacencies of the peignoir” in “Sunday Morning,” a poem by this author of “Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.”

Robert Hayden wrote about one of these events taking place for “the Queen of Sunday” at the “Broken Hearts and Gates-Ajar.” Wallace Stevens’ “The Emperor of Ice Cream” is about preparations for one of these events.

answers: selectins [or CD62; or Cluster of Differentiation 62; prompt on lectin]
parts: Name these glycoproteins that help leukocytes “roll” on the surface of vascular wall during infection.

During inflammation, endothelial cells release storage granules called Weible-Palade bodies containing P-selectins and this other glycoprotein critical for hemostasis. Mutations in this molecule cause the most common form of inherited blood-clotting disorder.

Circulating tumor cells can recruit platelets, allowing them to bind to endothelial cell walls during this process where a cancer cell breaks away from the primary tumor and migrates to a secondary site.
Identify this American philosopher who taught at Pitt and Chicago and whose unfinished commentary on Heidegger is titled Dasein Disclosed.

Haugeland wrote a book titled for “the very idea” of this discipline and edited two volumes of papers titled Mind Design that collect work in the philosophy of this technical field. This field’s aim is to make machines that think like people.
In a paper in Mind Design II, this philosopher defended symbol systems against connectionism. This former Rutgers professor theorized a “language of thought” and wrote The Modularity of Mind.

answers: Qianlong Emperor [or Hongli or Prince Bao of the First Rank]
parts: Name this grandson of the Kangxi Emperor who exterminated the Dzungars and crushed other frontier states in his Ten Great Campaigns.

Rebels among these people like Emin Khoja requested the aid of the Qianlong Emperor against the Dzungar Khanate. Contemporary China has rounded up millions of members of this ethnic group in reeducation camps in their province of Xinjiang.

Near the end of the Qianlong Emperor’s reign, this revolt broke out in Sichuan province. The imperial favorite Heshen embezzled appropriations for putting down this revolt, which inspired a later uprising of the Eight Trigrams.

This musical drama film follows filmmaker Mark and his HIV-positive roommate Roger in their Bohemian life in the East Village. This film was adapted from a popular Broadway musical created by Jonathan Larson.

In Philadelphia, the Tom Hanks-played Andy Beckett sues his former employer for discrimination after he is fired due to his AIDS diagnosis. Andy grows closer to his initially homophobic lawyer Joe Miller, who is played by this actor.
In this movie, writer Ned Weeks starts an organization called Gay Men’s Health Crisis to increase awareness of AIDS within the gay community. This TV movie starred Mark Ruffalo and Matt Bomer.

Name this film series. Kanye West was later forced to shut down building the aforementioned dome-like houses, inspired by Tunisian desert housing which was used to represent Tatooine (“TAH-too-een”) in this film series.

The Jedi Academy Library was ripped off from the Long Room in the library of this country’s oldest college. Medieval monasteries located in this country include Clonmacnoise (“CLON-muck-NEE-shuh”) and Skellig Michael, where the Ahch-To (“OCK-TOE”) scenes in The Last Jedi were filmed.
This architect designed the UAE's RAK Convention Center, which looks suspiciously like the Death Star, as well as Casa de Musica, which looks like a Jawa sandcrawler. This man also wrote S, M, L, XL.

answers: Cato the Younger [or Marcus Porcius Cato Uticensis; or clear equivalents to the junior Cato; prompt on Marcus Porcius Cato]
parts: Name this dictator whose defeat of the Optimates solidified his control over the Roman Republic after crossing the Rubicon River.

Julius Caesar decisively defeated the forces of Metellus Scipio and King Juba I of Numidia at this battle. During this battle, Caesar’s archers caused the Optimates’ war elephants to panic and trample their own men.

Following the Battle of Thapsus, this longtime opponent of Caesar disemboweled himself in Utica. With the support of Pompey, this famously incorruptible Optimate senator revoked Caesar’s proconsulate, prompting Caesar to cross the Rubicon.

Name this author of the short story “Half a Day,” which ends with the boy coming out of the school day to find that he is now old and the world has changed. This author also wrote a short story about police shooting people at a bus stop in “Under the Shelter.”
This novel by Mahfouz tells the story of the lives of the Kirshas, who own a cafe, a young woman named Hamida, and other residents of the titular street.
Mahfouz is the only Nobel prize winner from this Arabic-speaking country where his Cairo trilogy is set.

answers: making cloth [accept weaving; prompt on descriptions like spinning thread]
parts: Identify these animals, one of which instructs humanity to pour boiled grain over their dead in order to resurrect them in a myth from the Margi people.

Similar to the aforementioned story of the Margi people is one from these people, in which Unkulunkulu (“unk-oo-lunk-OO-loo”) makes people mortal because a lizard delivered his message of mortality before a chameleon could announce immortality.
In Yoruba myth, Olorun used her chameleon Agemo to help her defeat Olokun in a contest involving this task. Arachne was turned into a spider for defeating Athena in a contest involving this task.

answers: angle of attack [or AOA; or alpha; or angle of incidence]
parts: Name these large tubes used in aerodynamics research. In these tubes, air is blown past an object to predict how the object will fly.

Wind tunnel testing often measures the lift coefficient across different values of this angle. This angle is measured between a reference line on an airfoil and the relative velocity vector between the airfoil and the air.
The lift on an airfoil can be determined from the Kutta condition, which states that this quantity, symbolized gamma, will adjust in order to keep the rear stagnation point at the trailing edge.
